name: First Degree Burn
description: Superficial burn affecting only outer skin layer

steps.text: Remove from heat source immediately
Cool burn under cool running water for 10-20 minutes
Do not use ice or very cold water
Apply aloe vera or burn cream
Cover loosely with sterile bandage
Take over-the-counter pain reliever if needed
Remove from heat source and remove clothing near burn
Cool burn under cool running water for 15-20 minutes
Do not break blisters
Cover with non-stick sterile bandage
Seek medical attention for large burns or burns on face/hands
Watch for signs of infection

name: Third Degree Burn
description: Full thickness burn requiring emergency care

steps.text: Call 911 immediately
Do not remove burned clothing stuck to skin
Cover burn loosely with clean cloth
Elevate burned area above heart if possible
Monitor for shock - keep person warm
Do not apply creams, butter, or ointments
Protect yourself first: Wear gloves if available. Do not touch the chemical with bare hands. Ensure area is ventilated if fumes are present
Remove contaminated clothing: Cut away clothing if stuck to skin. Remove jewelry, watches, belts that may trap chemical. Work quickly but carefully
Flush immediately with water: Use large amounts of cool running water for at least 20 minutes. For eyes, hold lids open and flush from inner corner outward
Do NOT neutralize: Never apply substances to counteract the chemical (like vinegar on alkali burns). This causes a heat reaction that worsens the injury
Call Poison Control: 1-800-222-1222 (US). Have product container ready to identify the chemical. They provide specific treatment guidance
Continue flushing while calling: Do not stop water irrigation to make phone calls. Continue for minimum 20 minutes or until EMS arrives
Cover loosely: After thorough flushing, cover burn with clean, dry, loose bandage or cloth. Do not apply ointments, creams, or butter
Save product information: Keep the chemical container, label, or SDS (Safety Data Sheet) for emergency responders. This guides hospital treatment
Do not touch person if still in contact with electrical source
Turn off power source or separate person using non-conductive object
Call 911 immediately
Check for breathing and pulse - begin CPR if needed
Cover burns with sterile bandage
Monitor for cardiac problems even if person seems fine
Get out of the sun immediately
Cool skin with damp cloths or cool bath
Apply aloe vera gel or moisturizer
Take over-the-counter pain reliever
Drink plenty of water to prevent dehydration
Seek medical help if blistering, fever, or chills occur
